question: The Loschmidt number is the number of molecules in 1 cm³ of an ideal gas at STP. Its value is approximately:
The basicity of H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>3</sub> (phosphorous acid) is 2, not 3. This is because:
options: \text{H}_3\text{PO}_3\text{ has only 2 ionisable H}^+\text{; one H is directly bonded to P and is non-ionisable}
\text{H}_3\text{PO}_3\text{ has 3 ionisable H}^+\text{ but loses only 2 during reactions}
\text{Phosphorous acid is a weak acid and only partially ionises}
\text{The third H}^+\text{ is blocked by the phosphorus atom}
answer: \text{H}_3\text{PO}_3\text{ has only 2 ionisable H}^+\text{; one H is directly bonded to P and is non-ionisable}
tip: Only O-H bonds in acids are ionisable. P-H bonds are not acidic. H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>3</sub> has structure (HO)<sub>2</sub>P(=O)H — two O-H bonds (ionisable) and one P-H bond (non-ionisable) → basicity = 2.

question: In the Lewis structure of ozone (O₃) with one double bond and one single bond, the formal charges on central O, terminal double-bonded O, and terminal single-bonded O are respectively:
tip: Apply FC = V − LP − ½(BP) to each O separately. Central O: 6 − 2 − ½(6) = +1. Terminal O (double bond): 6 − 4 − ½(4) = 0. Terminal O (single bond): 6 − 6 − ½(2) = −1.

question: NH₃ has a higher dipole moment than NF₃ despite F being more electronegative. The correct reason is:
options: \text{N-H bond is longer than N-F bond}
\text{In NF}_3\text{, N-F bond dipoles oppose the lone pair dipole on N}
\text{NH}_3 \text{ has a larger bond angle than NF}_3
\text{NF}_3 \text{ has more lone pairs than NH}_3
answer: \text{In NF}_3\text{, N-F bond dipoles oppose the lone pair dipole on N}
tip: In NH₃: N–H dipoles reinforce the lone pair direction. In NF₃: N–F dipoles point away from N, opposing the lone pair → net μ is lower.

question: Ice has lower density than liquid water at 0°C because:

\text{Ice has a cage-like tetrahedral H-bonded structure with larger intermolecular spacing}
\text{H-bonds are completely absent in liquid water}
answer: \text{Ice has a cage-like tetrahedral H-bonded structure with larger intermolecular spacing}

question: For O₂ using MO theory (>14 electrons), which combination of bond order, magnetic character, and electron arrangement is correct?
options: BO = 2, \ \text{paramagnetic, two unpaired e}^- \text{ in } \pi^*_{2p_x} \text{ and } \pi^*_{2p_y}
answer: BO = 2, \ \text{paramagnetic, two unpaired e}^- \text{ in } \pi^*_{2p_x} \text{ and } \pi^*_{2p_y}
tip: O₂ has 16 electrons. Last 2 electrons fill π*2px and π*2py one each (Hund's rule) → paramagnetic. Nb = 10, Na = 6, BO = (10−6)/2 = 2.

\text{More electrons → larger size regardless of nuclear charge}
answer: \text{Same number of electrons; higher nuclear charge → smaller size}

question: The first ionisation enthalpy of N is greater than that of O, despite O having higher nuclear charge. The correct reason is:
options: \text{N has stable half-filled 2p³ configuration; O has 2p⁴ where one orbital has paired electrons — pairing repulsion makes it easier to remove an electron from O}
\text{N has smaller atomic size than O}
\text{O has higher electronegativity making it harder to remove electrons}
answer: \text{N has stable half-filled 2p³ configuration; O has 2p⁴ where one orbital has paired electrons — pairing repulsion makes it easier to remove an electron from O}

question: Electron gain enthalpy of F is less negative than that of Cl despite F being more electronegative. The reason is:
options: \text{F has very small size and high charge density — the added electron experiences strong electron-electron repulsion in the compact 2p orbital}
answer: \text{F has very small size and high charge density — the added electron experiences strong electron-electron repulsion in the compact 2p orbital}
tip: Same reasoning applies to O vs S: electron gain enthalpy of S is more negative than O. Small size + high charge density = more repulsion for incoming electron.

question: The Zeff of the 2s electron in Be (atomic number 4, configuration 1s² 2s²) using Slater's rules is:
tip: For 2s electron in Be: σ = (1 × 0.35 from the other 2s) + (2 × 0.85 from 1s electrons) = 0.35 + 1.70 = 2.05. Zeff = 4 − 2.05 = 1.95.

question: Among 3d transition elements, Cr (Z=24) and Cu (Z=29) have anomalously higher IE₂. The reason is:
options: \text{After losing one electron, Cr becomes [Ar]3d⁵ (half-filled) and Cu becomes [Ar]3d¹⁰ (fully-filled) — both are extra stable}
\text{Cr and Cu are larger than neighbouring elements}
\text{Both have higher nuclear charges than neighbours}
\text{Cr and Cu form stronger metallic bonds}
answer: \text{After losing one electron, Cr becomes [Ar]3d⁵ (half-filled) and Cu becomes [Ar]3d¹⁰ (fully-filled) — both are extra stable}

question: In Mendeleev's periodic table, Ar (atomic mass 39.9) was placed before K (atomic mass 39.1), violating the law of increasing atomic masses. This anomaly was resolved by Moseley because:
options: \text{Atomic number of Ar (18) < atomic number of K (19) — arranging by atomic number eliminates the anomaly}
\text{Mendeleev made an error in measuring atomic masses}
\text{Ar and K are isotopes of the same element}
\text{The anomaly was never resolved and remains a defect}
answer: \text{Atomic number of Ar (18) < atomic number of K (19) — arranging by atomic number eliminates the anomaly}

question: The IUPAC name for element with atomic number 106 is:
tip: IUPAC roots: 1=un, 0=nil, 6=hex → 106 = un-nil-hex-ium = Unnilhexium. Symbol: first letters of each root = Unh.

question: Electronegativity of carbon in different hybridisation states follows the order:
tip: Electronegativity increases with % s-character. sp has 50% s-character, sp² has 33%, sp³ has 25%. More s-character → electrons held closer to nucleus → higher electronegativity.

question: The diagonal relationship exists between Li and Mg, Be and Al, B and Si. The property that makes diagonal pairs similar is:
options: \text{Similar ionic radii and polarising power (charge/size ratio)}
answer: \text{Similar ionic radii and polarising power (charge/size ratio)}

question: Noble gases have positive electron gain enthalpies. This means:
options: \text{Energy must be supplied to add an electron — they resist gaining electrons due to stable filled configurations}
\text{Noble gases easily gain electrons to form stable anions}

question: Using the Third Law, the absolute entropy of a substance at temperature T can be found from the integral. Which expression correctly represents this?
tip: Since S = 0 at 0 K (Third Law), integrating dS = Cp dT/T from 0 to T gives absolute entropy. This is why Third Law enables absolute entropy measurements unlike ΔU or ΔH.

question: The boiling point order among alcohols, ethers, and alkanes of comparable molecular weight is:
Lucas test is used to distinguish between primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols. The reagent used is:
In Lucas test, which alcohol gives an immediate turbidity at room temperature?
options: \text{All give turbidity at the same rate}

question: Williamson synthesis is the best method for preparing ethers. It involves reaction of an alkyl halide with:
The acidity order among phenol, ethanol, water and carbonic acid is:
Dehydration of alcohols to alkenes requires which conditions?
tip: At 413 K, dehydration gives ether (two alcohol molecules). At 443 K (higher temp), dehydration gives alkene (one alcohol molecule). Temperature determines the product.

question: Oxidation of a primary alcohol with acidic K2Cr2O7 gives:
Kolbe's reaction involves heating sodium phenoxide with CO2 under pressure to give:
Reimer-Tiemann reaction of phenol with CHCl3 and NaOH gives:
Victor Meyer test distinguishes primary, secondary, and tertiary alcohols by the final colour produced. Match the correct combination: 1° gives red, 2° gives blue, 3° gives:
tip: Victor Meyer: alcohol → alkyl iodide (PI3) → nitroso compound (AgNO2) → with NaOH + Liebermann nitroso reagent → colour. 3° has no alpha-H → cannot form nitroso compound → no colour. 1° red, 2° blue, 3° colourless.

question: The reaction of alcohol with SOCl2 in the presence of pyridine proceeds with:
Phenol is more acidic than ethanol. The main reason is:

\text{The O-H bond in phenol is longer than in ethanol}
answer: \text{Phenoxide ion is resonance-stabilised; ethoxide ion is not}

question: Preparation of phenol industrially from cumene involves oxidation of cumene followed by:
Ethylene glycol is a diol. Its IUPAC name is:
When diethyl ether reacts with excess HI, the products are:
tip: With excess HI: first cleavage gives C2H5I + C2H5OH, then the alcohol reacts with the second HI to give C2H5I + H2O. Final products: 2 moles of ethyl iodide.

question: Nitration of phenol with dilute HNO3 at room temperature gives a mixture of:
o-nitrophenol has a lower boiling point than p-nitrophenol. The reason is:
options: \text{o-isomer forms intramolecular H-bond; p-isomer forms intermolecular H-bond}
\text{p-isomer forms intramolecular H-bond; o-isomer forms intermolecular H-bond}
answer: \text{o-isomer forms intramolecular H-bond; p-isomer forms intermolecular H-bond}

question: The reaction of phenol with bromine water (not in CS2) gives:
Absolute alcohol (100% ethanol) is prepared from rectified spirit (95.6% ethanol) by:
Why can phenol not be converted to phenyl chloride using PCl5 or SOCl2 under normal conditions, unlike alcohols?
options: \text{C-O bond in phenol has partial double bond character due to resonance with ring}
\text{Phenol is a liquid and cannot react with solid PCl}_5
\text{The OH group in phenol is too acidic to be replaced}
\text{Phenyl carbocation is too stable to form}
answer: \text{C-O bond in phenol has partial double bond character due to resonance with ring}
tip: Exactly analogous to vinyl chloride being unreactive. The lone pair on O delocalises into the ring → C-O gets partial double bond character → very hard to break. This is why phenol needs special conditions (e.g., POCl3 + pyridine) to give chlorobenzene.

question: The reagent used to oxidise a secondary alcohol specifically to a ketone without further oxidation is:
Which of the following correctly distinguishes phenol from ethanol using FeCl3 solution?
options: \text{Phenol gives violet/purple colour; ethanol gives no colour}
\text{Ethanol gives violet colour; phenol gives no colour}
\text{Phenol gives yellow colour; ethanol gives red colour}
answer: \text{Phenol gives violet/purple colour; ethanol gives no colour}

question: Methanol is called wood spirit because it was originally obtained by:
Clemmensen reduction converts a ketone to an alkane using:
In Williamson synthesis, why is it not possible to prepare an ether with a tertiary alkyl group using a tertiary alkyl halide?
options: \text{Tertiary alkyl halides undergo elimination (E2) with alkoxide instead of SN2 substitution}
\text{Tertiary alkyl halides are too stable to react}
\text{Alkoxide is too weak a nucleophile for tertiary halides}
answer: \text{Tertiary alkyl halides undergo elimination (E2) with alkoxide instead of SN2 substitution}
tip: Alkoxide is a strong base as well as a nucleophile. With 3° alkyl halides (bulky), the E2 elimination pathway dominates over SN2 substitution. To make tert-butyl ether, use tert-butanol + primary alkyl halide instead.

question: The reaction of phenol with phthalic anhydride in the presence of conc. H2SO4 gives a dye used as an acid-base indicator. This dye is:
The effect of an electron-withdrawing group (like -NO2) at ortho/para position on phenol's acidity is:
options: \text{Increases acidity by stabilising phenoxide ion further through resonance}
\text{Increases acidity only if at meta position}
answer: \text{Increases acidity by stabilising phenoxide ion further through resonance}
tip: -NO2 at o/p delocalises the negative charge of phenoxide further onto the nitro group via resonance → phenoxide more stable → acid stronger. At meta, only inductive effect (weaker).

question: Fries rearrangement converts phenyl ester to hydroxyaryl ketone in the presence of AlCl3. The product from phenyl acetate is:
Glycerol (propane-1,2,3-triol) on treatment with conc. H2SO4 at 440 K gives:
Phenol reacts with CO2 in Kolbe reaction at 400K and 4-7 atm. However, phenol does NOT react with CO2 under normal conditions even though phenol is a stronger acid than H2CO3. The reason is:
options: \text{Phenol reacts as sodium phenoxide (PhO}^-\text{Na}^+\text{), not free phenol; phenoxide is a better nucleophile than CO}_2\text{ is electrophile at STP}
\text{CO}_2\text{ is a weaker electrophile than PhO}^-\text{ is nucleophile at all conditions}
\text{Phenol is a weaker acid than H}_2\text{CO}_3\text{ at high temperature}
\text{High pressure is needed only to dissolve CO}_2\text{, not for the reaction}
answer: \text{Phenol reacts as sodium phenoxide (PhO}^-\text{Na}^+\text{), not free phenol; phenoxide is a better nucleophile than CO}_2\text{ is electrophile at STP}
tip: The apparent contradiction: phenol is a weaker acid than H2CO3, yet PhONa + CO2 + H2O → PhOH + NaHCO3 (phenol displaced). This is because the Kolbe reaction uses PhO-Na+, not free PhOH. Sodium phenoxide (a strong nucleophile) attacks CO2 at high pressure. The product salicylate is then acidified to give salicylic acid.

question: Hydroboration-oxidation of propene gives 1-propanol. The addition is:
Oxymercuration-demercuration of propene gives 2-propanol. The addition follows:
Methanol is manufactured industrially from water gas. The reagents and conditions are:
In fermentation of glucose to ethanol, the enzyme that converts glucose to ethanol and CO2 is:
Cleavage of methyl tert-butyl ether (CH3-O-C(CH3)3) with HI proceeds via SN1 or SN2? Which bond breaks and what are the products?
options: \text{SN1: tert-butyl C-O breaks; products are tert-butyl iodide + methanol}
\text{SN2: methyl C-O breaks; products are methyl iodide + tert-butanol}
\text{SN2: tert-butyl C-O breaks; products are tert-butyl iodide + methanol}
\text{SN1: methyl C-O breaks; products are methyl iodide + tert-butanol}
answer: \text{SN1: tert-butyl C-O breaks; products are tert-butyl iodide + methanol}
tip: Ether cleavage rule: the more substituted C-O bond breaks. 3° carbocation forms easily (SN1) → I- attacks → tert-BuI + CH3OH. If both groups were primary, SN2 would operate and the less hindered C-O would break.

question: Liebermann nitroso test is used to detect phenols. The sequence of observations when phenol reacts with NaNO2 and H2SO4, then NaOH, then acid is:
options: \text{Green in acid} \rightarrow \text{Red in alkali} \rightarrow \text{Green on acidification}
\text{Red in acid} \rightarrow \text{Blue in alkali} \rightarrow \text{Red on acidification}
\text{Blue in acid} \rightarrow \text{Green in alkali} \rightarrow \text{Blue on acidification}
\text{Yellow in acid} \rightarrow \text{Violet in alkali} \rightarrow \text{Yellow on acidification}
answer: \text{Green in acid} \rightarrow \text{Red in alkali} \rightarrow \text{Green on acidification}

question: Coupling reaction of phenol with benzene diazonium chloride in alkaline medium gives:
tip: Alkaline medium converts phenol to phenoxide ion (better nucleophile/activated ring). Diazonium ion (weak electrophile) attacks para position → -N=N- linkage forms → azo dye.

question: Ethylene glycol reacts with periodic acid (HIO4) to give:
tip: HIO4 cleaves vicinal diols (diols on adjacent carbons). Each -OH carbon becomes an aldehyde or ketone. Ethylene glycol (HO-CH2-CH2-OH) gives 2 molecules of HCHO.

question: Glycerol reacts with oxalic acid on heating to give acrolein via:

Hydroboration-oxidation gives anti-Markovnikov alcohol while acid-catalysed hydration gives Markovnikov alcohol from the same alkene. With 3,3-dimethylbut-1-ene, acid-catalysed hydration gives a rearranged product (2,3-dimethylbutan-2-ol) but hydroboration-oxidation gives the unrearranged product (3,3-dimethylbutan-1-ol). This is because:
options: \text{Hydroboration has no carbocation intermediate — BH}_3\text{ adds as a concerted syn process; no 1,2-shift possible}
\text{Hydroboration proceeds via a carbocation but the boron blocks rearrangement}
\text{Acid hydration also gives no rearrangement; the question premise is incorrect}
\text{Both proceed via carbocations, but hydroboration uses a bulkier borane that prevents shift}
answer: \text{Hydroboration has no carbocation intermediate — BH}_3\text{ adds as a concerted syn process; no 1,2-shift possible}
tip: This is the core reason hydroboration-oxidation is superior for sensitive substrates. Acid hydration: forms carbocation → 1,2-hydride or methyl shift → rearranged product. Hydroboration: four-membered cyclic transition state, concerted, no ionic intermediate → absolutely no rearrangement.

question: The nucleophilic addition reactivity order for carbonyl compounds is:
Rosenmund reduction converts an acyl chloride to an aldehyde using:
Tollens reagent is ammoniacal silver nitrate. The product deposited on the inner wall of the test tube when an aldehyde is added is:
Clemmensen reduction converts a carbonyl group to a methylene group using:
Aldol condensation requires at least one alpha-hydrogen. The product of aldol condensation of ethanal with dilute NaOH is:
tip: Aldol condensation gives the beta-hydroxy aldehyde first (3-hydroxybutanal). On heating or with stronger base, it dehydrates to but-2-enal (crotonaldehyde).

question: Cannizzaro reaction is shown by aldehydes with no alpha-hydrogen. In the reaction of benzaldehyde with conc. NaOH, the products are:
Fehling solution gives a reddish-brown precipitate with aldehydes. The precipitate formed is:
Haloform reaction occurs with methyl ketones (or acetaldehyde) treated with NaOX. The organic product alongside haloform is:
Stephen reaction converts a nitrile to an aldehyde. The reagents used are:
Benzaldehyde does NOT give Fehling test or aldol condensation, but DOES give Tollens test and Cannizzaro reaction. Which combination of properties correctly explains both observations simultaneously?
options: \text{No alpha-H (no aldol/Fehling impossible) — wait: Fehling fails due to steric/electronic effects of Ph group, not alpha-H; Tollens works as it is still an aldehyde}

\text{Benzaldehyde has no alpha-H: no aldol. Fehling fails because aromatic aldehydes are mild reducing agents insufficient to reduce Cu}^{2+}\text{. Tollens works as Ag}^+\text{ is a milder oxidant. Cannizzaro: no alpha-H present}
\text{Benzaldehyde has alpha-H on the ring, preventing aldol}
\text{Benzaldehyde reduces both Tollens and Fehling equally}
answer: \text{Benzaldehyde has no alpha-H: no aldol. Fehling fails because aromatic aldehydes are mild reducing agents insufficient to reduce Cu}^{2+}\text{. Tollens works as Ag}^+\text{ is a milder oxidant. Cannizzaro: no alpha-H present}
tip: Key distinctions: (1) Aldol needs alpha-H — PhCHO has none. (2) Fehling needs a stronger reducing aldehyde — aromatic aldehydes can't reduce Cu2+ to Cu2O. (3) Tollens uses Ag+ which is easier to reduce — PhCHO manages this. (4) Cannizzaro: only aldehydes with no alpha-H, PhCHO qualifies.

question: Wolff-Kishner reduction converts a carbonyl group to a methylene group using:
Gattermann-Koch synthesis prepares benzaldehyde from benzene using:
Wittig reaction converts a carbonyl compound to an alkene using:
The product of reaction between a ketone and hydroxylamine (NH2OH) is called:

Popoff's rule governs oxidative cleavage of unsymmetrical ketones. The cleavage point is such that:
options: \text{The keto group stays with the smaller alkyl group}
\text{The keto group stays with the larger alkyl group}
\text{Cleavage occurs only at the alpha carbon}
answer: \text{The keto group stays with the smaller alkyl group}

question: Cross aldol condensation between an aromatic aldehyde and an aliphatic aldehyde/ketone in the presence of base is specifically called:
Reformatsky reaction involves reaction of a carbonyl compound with zinc and an alpha-bromo ester to give:
Reaction of formaldehyde with excess ammonia gives hexamethylenetetramine (urotropine). Urotropine on controlled nitration gives:

Benzoin condensation between two molecules of benzaldehyde in the presence of alcoholic KCN gives benzoin. Why does this reaction NOT occur with aliphatic aldehydes having alpha-H, and why does it require CN- specifically?
options: \text{Alpha-H aldehydes preferentially undergo aldol; CN}^-\text{ acts as a nucleophile and umpolung catalyst — it attacks carbonyl, making that carbon nucleophilic to attack the second PhCHO}
\text{CN}^-\text{ acts only as a base to remove alpha-H in aliphatic aldehydes causing aldol instead}
\text{Benzoin condensation uses CN}^-\text{ only as a leaving group, not a catalyst}
\text{Aliphatic aldehydes cannot form cyanohydrins, so the reaction fails}
answer: \text{Alpha-H aldehydes preferentially undergo aldol; CN}^-\text{ acts as a nucleophile and umpolung catalyst — it attacks carbonyl, making that carbon nucleophilic to attack the second PhCHO}
tip: Umpolung: CN- adds to PhCHO → cyanohydrin carbanion → this carbanion (now nucleophilic at what was the electrophilic carbonyl C) attacks second PhCHO → after proton transfer and CN- expulsion → benzoin. With aliphatic aldehydes having alpha-H, aldol pathway is faster and dominates.

question: Etard reaction converts toluene to benzaldehyde using:
In Schmidt reaction, an aldehyde reacts with hydrazoic acid (HN3) in the presence of conc. H2SO4 to give:
In acetal formation from an aldehyde and excess alcohol, the first intermediate formed is a hemiacetal. The correct sequence and catalyst required are:
tip: Acid catalyst (HCl gas) protonates the carbonyl oxygen, making the carbon more electrophilic for ROH attack → hemiacetal. Second ROH attacks, water is lost → acetal. Base cannot catalyse this — acetal formation is acid-catalysed only.

question: Polymerisation of 3 moles of formaldehyde gives trioxane (metaformaldehyde), while polymerisation of 3 moles of acetaldehyde gives:

Knoevenagel reaction involves condensation of a carbonyl compound with an active methylene compound (like malonic acid) in the presence of base. The product after decarboxylation of malonic acid intermediate is:
tip: When R = CH3, product is crotonic acid. When R = C6H5, product is cinnamic acid (C6H5-CH=CH-COOH).

question: Addition of an aldehyde or ketone with sodium bisulphite (NaHSO3) gives a white crystalline addition product. This reaction is used for:
Schiff's reagent (decolourised rosaniline/magenta solution) gives pink colour with aldehydes but NOT with ketones. The one exception — which aldehyde does NOT give pink colour with Schiff's reagent?
options: \text{Formaldehyde (HCHO) — gives pink that is not discharged by H}_2\text{SO}_4\text{, unlike others}
answer: \text{Formaldehyde (HCHO) — gives pink that is not discharged by H}_2\text{SO}_4\text{, unlike others}
tip: All aldehydes give pink with Schiff's reagent. The distinction is that formaldehyde gives a pink colour that is NOT decolourised on adding H2SO4, while other aldehydes give pink that IS decolourised. This is the basis of distinguishing HCHO from other aldehydes using Schiff's.

question: Tischenko reaction is a modified Cannizzaro reaction. The reaction of acetaldehyde in the presence of Al(OC2H5)3 gives:
Perkin reaction involves condensation of an aromatic aldehyde with acetic anhydride in the presence of sodium acetate to give:

Acetaldehyde undergoes both aldol condensation AND Cannizzaro reaction under different conditions, while formaldehyde undergoes ONLY Cannizzaro reaction and benzaldehyde undergoes ONLY Cannizzaro reaction. Which combination of reasons correctly explains all three?
options: \text{CH}_3\text{CHO: has alpha-H (aldol possible) and no special stabilisation (Cannizzaro possible with conc. base); HCHO: no alpha-H, only Cannizzaro; PhCHO: no alpha-H, only Cannizzaro}
\text{CH}_3\text{CHO: undergoes only aldol; HCHO and PhCHO: undergo only Cannizzaro}
\text{All three undergo both reactions under the same conditions}
\text{HCHO undergoes aldol; PhCHO and CH}_3\text{CHO undergo Cannizzaro}
answer: \text{CH}_3\text{CHO: has alpha-H (aldol possible) and no special stabilisation (Cannizzaro possible with conc. base); HCHO: no alpha-H, only Cannizzaro; PhCHO: no alpha-H, only Cannizzaro}
tip: Alpha-H is the deciding factor: if present → aldol is preferred under dil. base; Cannizzaro needs conc. base and competes only if alpha-H reactions are suppressed. HCHO has no alpha-H and no ring — only Cannizzaro. PhCHO has no alpha-H (no aliphatic alpha-C) — only Cannizzaro. CH3CHO has alpha-H — aldol under dil. base, Cannizzaro possible with conc. NaOH but rare.

question: Gabriel phthalimide synthesis is used to prepare only primary amines. The reaction cannot be used to prepare primary aryl amines because:
options: \text{Aryl halides do not undergo nucleophilic substitution with potassium phthalimide}
\text{Aryl halides react too fast with phthalimide}
\text{Phthalimide does not dissolve in the presence of aryl halides}
answer: \text{Aryl halides do not undergo nucleophilic substitution with potassium phthalimide}

question: Carbylamine reaction is used as a test for primary amines only. The reagents are:
The boiling point order among isomeric amines (same molecular formula) is:
tip: Tertiary amines have no N-H bond → no intermolecular H-bonding → lowest BP. Primary has two N-H bonds → strongest H-bonding → highest BP.

question: Diazotisation of aniline requires temperature of 273-278 K. Excess HCl is added because:
options: \text{To prevent coupling of diazonium salt with undiazotised aniline}
\text{To stabilise the diazonium salt as a solid}
answer: \text{To prevent coupling of diazonium salt with undiazotised aniline}

question: Reduction of nitrobenzene with Zn/NaOH gives:
tip: Memory aid for nitrobenzene reduction products by medium — Acid: aniline. Neutral (Zn/NH4Cl): N-phenylhydroxylamine. Alkaline (Zn/NaOH): azobenzene. Strongly alkaline (Zn/NaOH + ethanol): hydrazobenzene.

question: Hinsberg's test distinguishes 1°, 2°, and 3° amines using benzenesulphonyl chloride. Which amine gives a product insoluble in alkali?
tip: 1° amine → sulphonamide with acidic N-H → soluble in alkali. 2° amine → sulphonamide with no N-H → insoluble in alkali. 3° amine → no reaction.

question: Aniline cannot be directly nitrated with HNO3/H2SO4 at room temperature because:
options: \text{Aniline gets oxidised/protonated; amino group is acetylated first to protect it}
\text{Aniline is insoluble in the nitrating mixture}
\text{Nitration requires higher temperature than aniline can withstand}
\text{HNO}_3\text{ reacts with aniline to give a salt, not a nitro compound}
answer: \text{Aniline gets oxidised/protonated; amino group is acetylated first to protect it}

question: Sulphonation of aniline gives sulphanilic acid as the major product. Sulphanilic acid exists as a zwitterion because:
options: \text{The -NH}_2\text{ group gets protonated and the -SO}_3\text{H group loses a proton intramolecularly}
\text{Sulphonic acid group donates a proton to water}
\text{The benzene ring carries both positive and negative resonance structures}
answer: \text{The -NH}_2\text{ group gets protonated and the -SO}_3\text{H group loses a proton intramolecularly}

question: In Sandmeyer reaction, benzene diazonium chloride gives chlorobenzene using CuCl/HCl. The Gattermann reaction achieves the same product using:

In aqueous solution, the basicity order of methylamines is (CH3)2NH > CH3NH2 > (CH3)3N > NH3, yet in gas phase (CH3)3N > (CH3)2NH > CH3NH2 > NH3. The reason for the reversal of trimethylamine in aqueous solution is:
options: \text{(CH}_3\text{)}_3\text{N cannot form H-bonds with water (no N-H); solvation of the bulky trimethylammonium ion is poor, destabilising it}
\text{(CH}_3\text{)}_3\text{N has the highest +I effect, making it too basic}
\text{(CH}_3\text{)}_3\text{N reacts with water to give a precipitate}
\text{Trimethylamine has a lower lone pair availability due to steric effects of three methyl groups}
answer: \text{(CH}_3\text{)}_3\text{N cannot form H-bonds with water (no N-H); solvation of the bulky trimethylammonium ion is poor, destabilising it}
tip: Basicity in solution = inductive effect + solvation of conjugate acid. Trimethylammonium ion (no N-H) is poorly solvated → conjugate acid less stable → base appears weaker. In gas phase, only +I effect operates → more methyl groups = stronger base.

question: Hofmann bromamide reaction converts RCONH2 to RNH2. The amine product has:
options: \text{Same number of carbons as the amide}

question: Coupling reaction of benzene diazonium chloride with aniline in slightly acidic medium gives:
tip: Coupling with aniline (pH slightly acidic) → yellow dye. Coupling with phenol (pH 9-10, alkaline) → orange dye.

question: Deamination of benzene diazonium chloride using hypophosphorous acid (H3PO2) gives:
Reaction of primary aliphatic amine with HNO2 (NaNO2 + HCl) gives:
options: \text{Diazonium salt which is unstable and immediately decomposes to alcohol + N}_2
answer: \text{Diazonium salt which is unstable and immediately decomposes to alcohol + N}_2

question: Ammonolysis of alkyl halides gives a mixture of 1°, 2°, 3° amines and quaternary salt. To maximise primary amine yield, the condition used is:
Aromatic amines are weaker bases than aliphatic amines. The reason is:
options: \text{Lone pair on N is delocalised into the benzene ring via resonance, reducing availability for protonation}
\text{The benzene ring donates electrons to nitrogen, making it too electron-rich}
\text{Aromatic amines form stronger H-bonds with water than aliphatic amines}
answer: \text{Lone pair on N is delocalised into the benzene ring via resonance, reducing availability for protonation}

question: o-substituted anilines are weaker bases than aniline regardless of whether the substituent is electron-donating or electron-withdrawing. This is called:
options: \text{Ortho effect (due to steric and electronic factors)}
answer: \text{Ortho effect (due to steric and electronic factors)}

question: Reduction of nitrobenzene with Zn/NH4Cl (neutral medium) gives:
Aniline does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reaction. The reason is:
options: \text{AlCl}_3\text{ forms a salt with -NH}_2\text{, making N positively charged — this strongly deactivates the ring}
\text{Aniline is insoluble in the reaction medium}
\text{Acyl chlorides react with the amine group instead of the ring}
answer: \text{AlCl}_3\text{ forms a salt with -NH}_2\text{, making N positively charged — this strongly deactivates the ring}

question: Bromination of aniline with Br2/H2O gives 2,4,6-tribromoaniline immediately, while bromination of benzene requires Br2/FeBr3 and gives monobromobenzene. The correct explanation for both observations is:
options: \text{-NH}_2\text{ strongly activates all three ortho/para positions via +M effect — no catalyst needed and all three positions substitute. Benzene is unactivated — needs Lewis acid catalyst and only one substitution occurs under mild conditions}
\text{Water acts as catalyst for aniline bromination}
\text{Aniline has three times the molecular weight of benzene}
\text{Bromine water is a stronger brominating agent than Br}_2\text{/FeBr}_3
answer: \text{-NH}_2\text{ strongly activates all three ortho/para positions via +M effect — no catalyst needed and all three positions substitute. Benzene is unactivated — needs Lewis acid catalyst and only one substitution occurs under mild conditions}
tip: To get monobromination of aniline: protect the -NH2 by acetylation first → reduced activation → monosubstitution. Deprotect after.

question: Reaction of secondary amine with HNO2 (NaNO2 + HCl) gives:
Zinin reduction selectively reduces one -NO2 group in m-dinitrobenzene. The reagent used is:
tip: Zinin reduction is the only method that selectively reduces one -NO2 without touching the other. Product: m-nitroaniline from m-dinitrobenzene.

question: Electrolytic reduction of nitrobenzene in dilute H2SO4 (acidic medium) gives:
tip: p-aminophenol is industrially important — it is used to make paracetamol (acetaminophen). This is the only route from nitrobenzene that gives a phenol product.

question: Hofmann elimination involves exhaustive methylation of an amine followed by treatment with Ag2O/H2O and heating. The alkene formed is:
tip: Hofmann vs Saytzeff: Hofmann elimination gives the less substituted (less stable) alkene because the bulky trimethylamine leaving group forces the base to abstract the more accessible (less hindered) beta-H.

question: Primary nitroalkanes give nitrolic acid with HNO2, which turns red with NaOH. Secondary nitroalkanes give pseudo nitrol, which turns blue with NaOH. What do tertiary nitroalkanes give with HNO2?
tip: Pattern: HNO2 with nitroalkanes requires alpha-H. 1° has two alpha-H → nitrolic acid (red with NaOH). 2° has one alpha-H → pseudo nitrol (blue with NaOH). 3° has no alpha-H → no reaction.

question: In Hofmann's method of separating amines, diethyl oxalate reacts with a mixture of 1°, 2°, and 3° amines. Which amine does NOT react?
Alkyl nitrile (RCN) and alkyl isocyanide (RNC) are isomers. At 250°C, alkyl isocyanide isomerises to:
Arenediazonium salts are more stable than alkyldiazonium salts. The reason is:
options: \text{Arenediazonium ion is resonance-stabilised — positive charge delocalises into the benzene ring}
\text{The N≡N bond is stronger in arenediazonium than alkyldiazonium}
\text{Arenediazonium ions form stronger ionic bonds with Cl}^-
answer: \text{Arenediazonium ion is resonance-stabilised — positive charge delocalises into the benzene ring}

question: Reduction of an alkyl nitrile (RCN) with Na/C2H5OH gives a primary amine (Mendius reduction). Reduction of RCN with SnCl2/HCl gives an imine hydrochloride which on hydrolysis gives:

In strong acidic medium, aniline is protonated to give anilinium ion. This changes the directing effect of the nitrogen group from ortho/para to meta. In nitration under these conditions, the products are a mixture of ortho, para (from unprotonated aniline) AND meta (from anilinium ion). Which observation correctly explains why the meta product is obtained at all, even though -NH2 is always o/p directing?
options: \text{In strongly acidic medium, a fraction of aniline exists as -NH}_3^+\text{ (anilinium ion) — this group is electron-withdrawing and meta-directing, so that fraction gives meta-nitroaniline}
\text{High temperature in acidic medium reverses the directing effect}
\text{HNO}_3\text{ itself changes the directing effect in the presence of H}_2\text{SO}_4
\text{Meta product arises from rearrangement of ortho product}
answer: \text{In strongly acidic medium, a fraction of aniline exists as -NH}_3^+\text{ (anilinium ion) — this group is electron-withdrawing and meta-directing, so that fraction gives meta-nitroaniline}

question: Which of the following is a non-reducing sugar?
tip: Among disaccharides, sucrose is the only non-reducing sugar because both anomeric carbons (C1 of glucose and C2 of fructose) are involved in the glycosidic bond — no free -CHO or hemiacetal group remains.

question: Glucose on acetylation with acetic anhydride gives a pentaacetate. This confirms:
Mutarotation is the spontaneous change in specific rotation of glucose in aqueous solution to an equilibrium value of +52.5°. It occurs because:
options: \alpha\text{-D-glucose (+111.5°) and }\beta\text{-D-glucose (+19.5°) interconvert via open-chain aldehyde form}
\text{The aldehyde group is oxidised by dissolved oxygen}
\text{Glucose undergoes ring opening to give sorbitol}
answer: \alpha\text{-D-glucose (+111.5°) and }\beta\text{-D-glucose (+19.5°) interconvert via open-chain aldehyde form}

question: The number of peptide bonds in a polypeptide made up of n amino acids is:

question: Glucose and fructose give the same osazone on treatment with excess phenyl hydrazine. This is because:
options: \text{C1 and C2 are involved in osazone formation — glucose and fructose have identical configurations at C3, C4 and C5}
\text{Both contain the same number of hydroxyl groups}
answer: \text{C1 and C2 are involved in osazone formation — glucose and fructose have identical configurations at C3, C4 and C5}
tip: Osazone destroys the structural difference at C1 and C2 — leaving C3–C5 intact. Since glucose and fructose share identical C3–C5 configurations, they give the same glucosazone.

question: Biuret test detects proteins. The colour produced when protein solution is treated with NaOH and dilute CuSO4 is:
Between adenine-thymine (A-T) and guanine-cytosine (G-C) base pairs in DNA, the number of hydrogen bonds are:
Fructose does not reduce bromine water but does reduce Tollens and Fehling reagents. The correct explanation is:
options: \text{Bromine water oxidises only aldehydes (aldoses); fructose is a ketose. Tollens/Fehling work in alkaline conditions where fructose isomerises to glucose via enolisation}
\text{Fructose has a different ring structure that prevents all oxidation}
\text{Bromine water is a weaker oxidant than Tollens reagent}
\text{Fructose reduces Tollens because it has more hydroxyl groups}
answer: \text{Bromine water oxidises only aldehydes (aldoses); fructose is a ketose. Tollens/Fehling work in alkaline conditions where fructose isomerises to glucose via enolisation}
tip: Bromine water test is selective for aldoses — it distinguishes aldose from ketose. Tollens/Fehling use alkaline medium → ketose isomerises to aldose → reduces the reagent. This is why Br2 water but not Tollens/Fehling can differentiate glucose from fructose.

tip: Common traps: Insulin decreases blood glucose (not increases). Glucagon increases blood glucose (opposite of insulin). Thyroxin stimulates metabolism — not sex organs (that's testosterone/estrogen).

question: Denaturation of a protein destroys its tertiary/secondary structure but not its primary structure. Which of the following does NOT cause denaturation?
tip: Denaturation disrupts secondary and tertiary structure (H-bonds, disulphide bonds, ionic bonds) without breaking peptide bonds. The primary structure (amino acid sequence) remains intact — that's why denaturation is different from hydrolysis.

question: Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar and does not give mutarotation. However, on hydrolysis it gives an equimolar mixture of glucose (+52.5°) and fructose (−92°), and the mixture is laevorotatory. This mixture is called invert sugar. The inversion of sign of rotation occurs because:
options: \text{Fructose has a higher magnitude of negative rotation (−92°) than glucose's positive rotation (+52.5°), so the mixture becomes net laevorotatory}
\text{Hydrolysis converts the dextrorotatory sucrose to two laevorotatory sugars}
\text{Both glucose and fructose are laevorotatory in the free state}
\text{The glycosidic bond cleavage reverses the optical activity of both sugars}
answer: \text{Fructose has a higher magnitude of negative rotation (−92°) than glucose's positive rotation (+52.5°), so the mixture becomes net laevorotatory}

Formic acid (HCOOH) is unique among carboxylic acids in reducing Tollens reagent, Fehling solution and acidified KMnO4. The correct reason for this exceptional reducing property is:
options: \text{HCOOH has an aldehyde-like H directly on the carbonyl carbon (H-COOH), allowing it to donate electrons like an aldehyde}
\text{HCOOH has the lowest molecular weight among acids}
\text{HCOOH is a diprotic acid unlike other monocarboxylic acids}
\text{HCOOH has no alkyl group to provide +I effect, making it more reactive}
answer: \text{HCOOH has an aldehyde-like H directly on the carbonyl carbon (H-COOH), allowing it to donate electrons like an aldehyde}
tip: Think of HCOOH as H-CO-OH — it has both carbonyl and hydroxyl, making it a hybrid of aldehyde and acid. That aldehyde character is why it reduces Tollens, Fehling, and KMnO4.

question: The ease of hydrolysis of acid derivatives follows the order:

tip: Pattern: 1,3-diacids (malonic) and lower → decarboxylation. 1,4-diacids (succinic) and 1,5-diacids (glutaric) → cyclic anhydride. Oxalic acid (1,2-diacid) → CO2 + CO + H2O (or HCOOH + CO2 depending on conditions).

question: Among the three nitrobenzoic acid isomers, Ka values are: o-NO2 (35.0×10-5) > p-NO2 (6.0×10-5) ≈ m-NO2 (32.0×10-5). The ortho isomer is the strongest acid despite -NO2 being a meta-director. The correct explanation for ortho being strongest is:
options: \text{Ortho -NO}_2\text{ exerts both -I and -M effects AND the ortho effect (steric inhibition of resonance of -COOH with ring reduces its donation, increasing acidity)}
\text{The ortho isomer has a lower pKa due to intramolecular H-bonding with -COOH}
answer: \text{Ortho -NO}_2\text{ exerts both -I and -M effects AND the ortho effect (steric inhibition of resonance of -COOH with ring reduces its donation, increasing acidity)}
tip: Ortho rule: any substituent at ortho position tends to make benzoic acid stronger than its para counterpart — steric strain forces -COOH out of the ring plane, disrupting its resonance and making the carboxylate more stable on ionisation.

question: Ammonolysis of an ester (RCOOR') with ammonia gives:

question: Reaction of an acid chloride (RCOCl) with KCN followed by hydrolysis gives:
Peracetic acid (CH3COOOH) is a weaker acid than acetic acid, even though it has an additional electronegative -OOH group. The correct reason is:
options: \text{Acetate ion (CH}_3\text{COO}^-\text{) is resonance-stabilised; peroxyacetate ion is not as well-stabilised due to lone pair repulsion between adjacent oxygens}
\text{Peracetic acid has higher molecular weight reducing acidity}
\text{The O-O bond in peracetic acid makes it less polar}
\text{Peracetic acid forms stronger intramolecular H-bonds reducing ionisation}
answer: \text{Acetate ion (CH}_3\text{COO}^-\text{) is resonance-stabilised; peroxyacetate ion is not as well-stabilised due to lone pair repulsion between adjacent oxygens}
tip: More electronegative substituent doesn't always mean stronger acid — the stability of the conjugate base matters. Here, O-O lone pair repulsion in peroxyacetate actually destabilises it, outweighing the inductive effect of -OOH.

question: Why is mercury (Hg) a liquid at room temperature, unlike other transition metals?

question: The magnetic moment of a transition metal ion is 5.92 BM. The number of unpaired electrons and the most likely ion are:

question: The purple colour of KMnO₄ is due to charge transfer, not d-d transition. This is because:
options: \text{Mn in KMnO}_4\text{ has a d}^0\text{ configuration with no unpaired d-electrons}
\text{Mn in KMnO}_4\text{ has a d}^5\text{ half-filled configuration}

answer: \text{Mn in KMnO}_4\text{ has a d}^0\text{ configuration with no unpaired d-electrons}
tip: Charge transfer: O²⁻ → O⁻ and Mn(VII) → Mn(VI). Only possible when energy levels on two atoms are close.

question: In the chromyl chloride test for Cl⁻, the red vapour of CrO₂Cl₂ is passed into NaOH solution. The sequence of observations is:

\text{Red vapours} \rightarrow \text{yellow Na}_2\text{CrO}_4\text{ solution} \rightarrow \text{yellow PbCrO}_4\text{ ppt on adding Pb(CH}_3\text{COO)}_2

\text{Eu}^{4+}\text{ and Yb}^{4+}\text{ are the stable +4 ions}

answer: \text{Eu}^{2+}\text{(f}^7\text{), Yb}^{2+}\text{(f}^{14}\text{) — reducing agents; Ce}^{4+}\text{(f}^0\text{), Tb}^{4+}\text{(f}^7\text{) — oxidising agents}

question: Lanthanoid contraction occurs because:

answer: \text{4f orbitals are large and diffuse with poor shielding; effective nuclear charge increases steadily}

question: A direct consequence of lanthanoid contraction is that Zr and Hf, and Nb and Ta have nearly identical sizes. They are called:

\text{Basic strength of Ln oxides/hydroxides decreases from La to Lu}
\text{5d series elements are larger than 4d series elements}
answer: \text{Basic strength of Ln oxides/hydroxides decreases from La to Lu}

question: The magnetic moment formula for lanthanoids is different from transition elements because:

answer: \mu = \sqrt{4S(S+1) + L(L+1)}\text{ (includes orbital contribution L); for 3d metals orbital contribution is quenched by ligand fields}

question: Misch metal is used in lighter flints. Its approximate composition is:
options: \text{Lanthanoid metals 94--95\%, Fe 5\%, traces of S, C, Ca, Al}
answer: \text{Lanthanoid metals 94--95\%, Fe 5\%, traces of S, C, Ca, Al}

question: Actinoids differ from lanthanoids in which key respect?
options: \text{Actinoids show variable OS up to +7; have greater tendency to form complexes; actinoid contraction > lanthanoid contraction}
\text{Actinoids have lower tendency to form complexes than lanthanoids}
\text{Actinoids all occur naturally; none are man-made}
answer: \text{Actinoids show variable OS up to +7; have greater tendency to form complexes; actinoid contraction > lanthanoid contraction}

question: Sc³⁺ and Ti⁴⁺ are colourless in solution, whereas Ti³⁺ is coloured. The reason is:
options: \text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ have d}^0\text{ configuration — no d-d transitions possible; Ti}^{3+}\text{ has d}^1\text{ — d-d transition possible}
\text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ are too small to absorb visible light}
\text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ have completely filled d}^{10}\text{ orbitals}
\text{Ti}^{3+}\text{ is coloured due to charge transfer, not d-d transitions}
answer: \text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ have d}^0\text{ configuration — no d-d transitions possible; Ti}^{3+}\text{ has d}^1\text{ — d-d transition possible}
tip: Rule: d⁰ and d¹⁰ ions are colourless (no d-d transitions). All others with partially filled d-orbitals are coloured.

question: Why do the 5d transition elements (e.g. Hf, Ta, W) have nearly the same atomic radii as the corresponding 4d elements (Zr, Nb, Mo), even though they are in a lower period?
options: \text{5d elements have fewer electrons than expected}
\text{Lanthanoid contraction: poor shielding of 4f electrons causes the 5d elements to be unusually small, offsetting the expected increase in size}
\text{5d elements have a higher nuclear charge which contracts them}
\text{4d and 5d elements have identical electronic configurations}
answer: \text{Lanthanoid contraction: poor shielding of 4f electrons causes the 5d elements to be unusually small, offsetting the expected increase in size}

question: Iodoform test gives a positive yellow precipitate with compounds containing which groups?
Addition of HBr to propene in the presence of peroxides gives 1-bromopropane as the major product instead of 2-bromopropane. This is because:
options: \text{Peroxides generate Br}^\bullet\text{; it adds to terminal carbon (less hindered) giving more stable radical at C2}
\text{Peroxides generate Br}^-\text{; it attacks the terminal carbon by SN2}
\text{Peroxides stabilise the secondary carbocation at C1}
answer: \text{Peroxides generate Br}^\bullet\text{; it adds to terminal carbon (less hindered) giving more stable radical at C2}
tip: Peroxide effect applies ONLY to HBr, not HCl or HI. Mechanism is free radical, not ionic. Br radical adds to terminal C → secondary radical at C2 → H adds to C2 → 1-bromopropane (anti-Markovnikov).

question: In SN1 reactions, partial racemisation occurs rather than complete racemisation. The correct reason is:
options: \text{Both frontal and backside attack occur on the planar carbocation, but backside is slightly preferred}
\text{Only backside attack occurs on the planar carbocation}
\text{The nucleophile attacks only from the front}
\text{The carbocation formed is tetrahedral, not planar}
answer: \text{Both frontal and backside attack occur on the planar carbocation, but backside is slightly preferred}
tip: Complete racemisation needs exactly 50:50 frontal and backside attack. Since the leaving group still partially shields one face even after departure, backside is slightly favoured — giving partial racemisation with slight excess of inverted product.

question: Halogens are deactivating but ortho/para directing in electrophilic substitution. This is because:

question: Vinyl chloride is far less reactive toward SN reactions, while benzyl chloride is far MORE reactive than ordinary alkyl chlorides in SN1. Which combination correctly explains BOTH?
options: \text{Vinyl: C-Cl has partial double bond character (resonance); Benzyl: carbocation resonance-stabilised by ring}
\text{Vinyl: sp}^2 \text{ carbon is larger; Benzyl: sp}^3 \text{ carbon is smaller}
\text{Vinyl: Cl is a poor leaving group; Benzyl: Cl is a better leaving group than usual}
\text{Vinyl: steric hindrance at sp}^2\text{; Benzyl: no steric hindrance at sp}^3
answer: \text{Vinyl: C-Cl has partial double bond character (resonance); Benzyl: carbocation resonance-stabilised by ring}
tip: Vinyl chloride: lone pair on Cl overlaps with pi bond → C-Cl acquires double bond character → very hard to break. Benzyl chloride: loss of Cl gives benzyl carbocation with 4 resonating structures across the ring → highly stable → SN1 very fast.
